author: Jessica Bernardo
title: Prefeitura guincha contêiner de ONG em São Paulo sem aviso prévio
text:
Prefeitura guincha contêiner de ONG em São Paulo sem aviso prévio
Contêiner guardava bicicletas de projeto social que ensina pessoas a pedalar. Prefeitura diz que equipamento estava abandonado
atualizado
Compartilhar notícia
São Paulo – Membros do Bike Anjo, projeto social que ensina pessoas a andarem de bicicleta em
São Paulo, afirmam que a Subprefeitura de Pinheiros guinchou um contêiner da organização sem aviso prévio, nesta terça-feira (13/8). O equipamento estava no Largo da Batata, na zona oeste da cidade, e guardava cerca de 30 bicicletas usadas pelos instrutores do projeto.
“Não tinha absolutamente nada nos avisando sobre a remoção. A gente foi pego completamente de surpresa”, diz uma das voluntárias da coordenação do Bike Anjo, Luciana Souza.
Um vídeo que circula nas
redes sociais mostra o momento em que o contêiner é guinchado.
Veja:
Desde 2015, o Bike Anjo utiliza o espaço do Largo da Batata para realizar oficinas gratuitas com alunos do projeto. As “aulas” acontecem todo último domingo do mês e já contaram com a participação de mais de 3 mil pessoas, segundo a organização.
Em nota, a
subprefeitura afirma que o equipamento foi retirado da praça porque estava em “situação de abandono”.
“O contêiner encontrava-se em estado precário, cercado de lixo e sem qualquer identificação ou número de processo oficial para sua instalação, não apresentando vínculo visível com a organização Bike Anjo ou com a municipalidade”, diz a pasta.
A subprefeitura afirma ainda que o proprietário do equipamento será orientado, ao entrar em contato com a gestão, a apresentar a documentação necessária e regularizar a situação pessoalmente.
A organização contesta a versão da administração municipal, diz que sempre limpava o entorno do local ao fazer as oficinas e cita que tinha autorização do subprefeito anterior da região, Leonardo Casal Santos, para permanecer na praça.
Luciana diz que a preocupação do grupo é fazer com que o contêiner seja devolvido sem nenhuma multa para o projeto. “O que a gente recebe de doação não é suficiente para pagar uma multa”, afirma a ciclista.
Todas as bicicletas que estavam guardadas no equipamento foram doadas para o Bike Anjo depois que o projeto teve os veículos anteriores furtados durante o Carnaval de 2020. Na ocasião, o contêiner foi arrombado por criminosos.

title: Evita este aeropuerto de Florida: es el peor para los controles de seguridad
text:
Si buscas un aeropuerto donde pasar menos tiempo en las filas de seguridad, el Aeropuerto Internacional de Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood en Florida podría no ser tu primera opción . Según un reciente estudio que analizó los tiempos de espera en los 31 aeropuertos más grandes de Estados Unidos , dicho lugar tiene la fila de control más larga de todos ellos.
Los datos revelan que los pasajeros allí pasan, en promedio, 15 minutos y 27 segundos en los controles de la TSA . Este promedio se obtuvo al recopilar tiempos de espera durante cada hora del día a lo largo de la semana y se destacaron los periodos de mayor y menor actividad.
Aunque la fila de seguridad puede ser extensa, una vez superada, podrás relajarte en tu puerta de embarque o disfrutar de una bebida en las salas de espera. Para ayudarte a planificar tu viaje, te contaremos cuáles son los aeropuertos más grandes de Estados Unidos con las filas de seguridad de la TSA más largas . Así, podrás tomar decisiones informadas y evitar sorpresas durante tu próximo viaje.

Largos tiempos de espera en seguridad: si las filas para los controles de seguridad son excesivamente largas y los tiempos de espera son altos. Retrasos frecuentes de vuelos: un alto número de retrasos y cancelaciones de vuelos puede afectar la percepción de calidad. Problemas con la limpieza y mantenimiento: aeropuertos que no mantienen sus instalaciones limpias y en buen estado suelen recibir malas calificaciones. Falta de servicios y comodidades: la ausencia de servicios básicos como restaurantes, tiendas y áreas de descanso puede hacer que sea considerado de baja calidad. Experiencias negativas del cliente: comentarios y quejas de los viajeros sobre el trato del personal, la gestión de equipajes y otros aspectos del servicio. author: Darryl K. Taft
title: Rust Gets Security, WASI 0.2 Support, Productivity Boost
text:
Rust Gets Security, WASI 0.2 Support, Productivity Boost
As the adoption of the
Rust programming language continues to rise, new challenges as well as advances have also arisen, including security issues, use with WebAssembly (WASM) and productivity benefits.
This week, the Rust team released Rust 1.77.2 to address a
critical vulnerability, identified as CVE-2024-24576. The vulnerability affects the Rust standard library on Windows when invoking batch files using the Command API with untrusted arguments. An attacker could potentially execute arbitrary shell commands by bypassing the argument escaping.
The vulnerability is considered critical for developers using batch files on Windows with untrusted arguments. No other platforms or use cases are affected. However, all Rust versions before 1.77.2 on Windows are affected if the code or its dependencies execute batch files with untrusted arguments.
The issue stems from the complex argument-splitting logic of cmd.exe on Windows, which required the standard library to implement custom escaping for arguments passed to batch files. However, the escaping logic was found to be insufficient, the Rust Security Response Working Group wrote in a
security advisory blog post.
As a mitigation, the Rust team improved the robustness of the escaping code and modified the Command API to return an InvalidInput error when it cannot safely escape an argument. The fix is included in Rust 1.77.2.
Rust for WebAssembly
Meanwhile, the Rust team has begun implementing first-class support for WebAssembly System Interface (WASI) 0.2 in the form of a dedicated new target, wrote
Yosh Wuyts, a Rust developer advocate at Microsoft, in a post on the Rust Blog.
This is important because Rust continues to be one of the best programming languages for
building WebAssembly applications and supporting infrastructure.
Rust 1.78, which will be available on May 2, will introduce new
wasm32-wasip1 (tier 2) and
wasm32-wasip2 (tier 3) targets.
wasm32-wasip1 is an effective rename of the existing wasm32-wasi target, freeing the target name up for an eventual WASI 1.0 release.
“Starting [with] Rust 1.78, users of WASI 0.1 are encouraged to begin migrating to the new
wasm32-wasip1 target before the existing
wasm32-wasi target is removed in Rust 1.84 (January 5th, 2025),” Wuyts wrote.
Moreover, “After nearly five years of work the
WASI 0.2 specification was recently stabilized,” Wuyts noted. “This work builds on WebAssembly Components (think: strongly-typed ABI for Wasm), providing standard interfaces for things like asynchronous IO, networking, and HTTP. This will finally make it possible to write asynchronous networked services on top of WASI, something which wasn’t possible using WASI 0.1.”
Rust Provides Two Times the Productivity of C++
Meanwhile, in a recent talk,
Lars Bergstrom, director of engineering at
Speaking at the
Rust Nation UK Conference in late March, Bergstrom said Google was “looking at comparing our rewrites of C++ code into Rust. And in every case, we’ve seen a decrease by more than 2x in the amount of effort required to both build the services in Rust, as well as maintain and update those services written in Rust. And so that’s a really huge thing for us because C++ code is very expensive…”
In February, Google
pledged $1 million to the Rust Foundation to improve the interoperability between the C++ and Rust programming languages. The goal of the effort is to get organizations to slowly migrate C++ code to Rust, according to The Rust Foundation.
“While Rust may not be suitable for all product applications, prioritizing seamless interoperability with C++ will accelerate wider community adoption, thereby aligning with the industry goals of improving memory safety,” Bergstrom wrote in a
blog post. In addition to being a director of engineering at Google, Bergstrom is both the Google director for the Android platform tools and libraries as well as the chair of the Rust Foundation Board.
Rust and Memory Safety
Bergstrom said the industry has grown aware of the challenges of using non-memory-safe languages, including
warnings from the White House.
“Now, I do want to admit unsafe code, we need to do more about it,” he said. “But I worry about unsafe code in the same way that my Java teams worry about JNI [Java Native Interface] code, in the same way, that my teams who are writing web services worry about the virtual machine and runtime — we always need to be improving the quality of the entire software stack…”
In February, the White House
Office of the National Cyber Director (ONCD) issued a recommendation that software development organizations begin to use memory-safe languages such as Rust for application and systems development, citing Rust as “one example of a memory-safe programming language.”
Busting Rust Myths
Last year, Bergstrom and
Kathy Brennan, a low-level Operating Systems Sr. User Experience Researcher, wrote a blog post debunking and confirming many of the common myths about Rust based on surveys of Google’s Rust developers — which roughly aligned with his talk at the Rust Nation UK event.
One thing the post confirmed is that Rust enables developers to deliver high-quality code.
“Android’s experience with Rust has been excellent. My team built the first major component keystore which is a medium-sized component with significant concurrency,” Bergstrom said in his talk. “We’re now three years in and it has been basically flawless. For those of you who haven’t worked in production commercial software, the words ‘basically flawless’ and systems code do not usually appear in the same sentence.”
He added that more than half of the developers surveyed found Rust code easier to review compared to code in other languages, and 85% felt more confident in the correctness of their team’s Rust code compared to code in other languages.
Bergstrom also noted that Rust is not difficult to learn — unlike its reputation as being hard.
He said surveys of Google developers show that it takes about two months for them to become sufficiently productive in Rust, similar to the time it takes for Java developers to become productive in
Kotlin — which is another effort Google is undergoing.
“We have a similar migration going on in the Java ecosystem where we’re moving people from Java to Kotlin,” Bergstrom said. “And the number that we use at Google to reflect about how long it takes us to take a Java developer and get them contributing to Kotlin is eight weeks.”
Moreover, Bergstrom noted that developers typically feel as productive in Rust as they were in their previous languages –C++, Java,
Python, Go — within four months.

author: Marzio G. Mian
title: Lungo il Volga, nel cuore della Russia profonda, restano corvi, qualche oca e tanti veleni. Mentre fiorisce il traffico illegale di guerra- Corriere.it
text: [ Un tetto fotovoltaico sul centro logistico: il nuovo ingrediente di sostenibilità della pasta](/pianeta2030/24_ottobre_10/tetto-fotovoltaico-centro-logistico-nuovo-ingrediente-sostenibilita-pasta-8e468bea-8719-11ef-a7e6-a8816a51a364.shtml) di Peppe Aquaro di Marzio G. Mian26 set 2024 Quando siamo partiti, sul Rialto del Valdaj, nella regione tra San Pietroburgo e Mosca, nel sottobosco della taiga, sotto i larici e gli abeti c’erano i bucaneve e i primi mirtilli e le fragoline selvatiche; giunti ad Astrakan, la steppa era tostata dal sole, sul delta del Volga sbocciavano i fiori di loto, le angurie erano già mature e dolcissime. Un mese di viaggio, seimila chilometri dentro gl’immensi spazi a esplorare l’ignoto, perché è questa oggi la Russia di Vladimir Putin: il Paese più grande del mondo è diventato quasi un altro pianeta; una larga fetta della Terra in pochi anni è uscita dai radar dell’informazione occidentale, sigillata dall’interno dalla paranoica repressione di regime e dall’esterno in quanto minaccia numero uno dell’ordine euro-atlantico. Nel nostro (pericoloso) viaggio nel cuore della Russia, durante la seconda estate dallo scoppio della guerra all’Ucraina, ci siamo sentiti quasi dei pionieri, perché mentre indagavamo l’impatto e gli effetti del conflitto nel Paese invasore non abbiamo mai incontrato uno straniero. L’obiettivo era ambizioso, provare a capire che cosa vuol dire essere russi mentre Putin ha lanciato la sua offensiva bellica e ideologica neo-imperiale. E abbiamo seguito la rotta maestra del Volga, il grande fiume lungo il quale da oltre mille anni si sono determinati l’identità, la storia, la cultura e la fede della Russia. “L’autobiografia di un popolo”, l’ha definito il direttore dell’Ermitage, Michail Piotrovskij. Un viaggio nell’umanità odierna e nella storia di luoghi che hanno segnato i destini del mondo – tra tutti Volgograd, l’ex Stalingrado – incontrando pope, badesse, imam, mercenari, imprenditori, vedove, studenti, scrittori, pacifisti, agenti della sicurezza... Ma anche esplorazione di paesaggi selvaggi, rurali e urbani: con l’autoisolamento della Russia, ancor più cupo che ai tempi bui dell’Urss, ci sono apparsi improvvisamente scenari esotici, parte del mistero, parte della risposta. Un enigma che ci ha accompagnato dalle sorgenti alla foce, dalla taiga alla steppa, attraversando foreste e sconfinate pianure, è stato ad esempio quello di una natura senza animaliLucci da lontano Astrakan, sul delta, già antico “centro commerciale” della via della Seta, è diventata cruciale per l’asse economico antioccidentale. I porti turistici sono chiusi e quelli mercantili presidiati dalle forze di sicurezza. Abbiamo osservato da lontano l’intensa attività di carico-scarico, decine di cargo e chiatte in attesa alla fonda. È l’hub dell’import-export clandestino di beni agricoli e di petrolio, ma anche di turbine, ricambi meccanici, medicinali, componentistica nucleare e droni. In città è cosa risaputa, e non fanno mistero del denaro fresco che circola. La signora Olesja Sergeeva, direttrice di una delle più importanti società produttrici di caviale, garantiva di venderne quanto nell’anteguerra, cinque tonnellate l’anno. E raccontava come il delta paga la devastazione del Volga. «Hanno manomesso la natura in un modo tale che sembra non riprendersi più», diceva. «Come Maksim Gor’kij, vedo nel Volga l’inesplicabile forza autodistruttiva dei russi». Raccontava che il Caspio nei decenni s’è abbassato di quattro metri a causa delle dighe del Volga. E le dighe hanno impedito agli storioni di risalire il fiume per riprodursi. Il resto l’hanno fatto gli scarichi. Gli unici storioni beluga sono ormai allevati. Nelle grandi città la guerra è solo un rumore di fondo, come quello di una caldaia o di un condizionatore. A Jaroslav, a Nizhni Novgorod, a Kazan i centri storici sono intasati di lavori pubblici, restauro di palazzi, ripristino di marciapiedi e tubature. Squadre di giardinieri municipali sono all’opera nei parchi pubblici insieme a decine di liceali obbligati a contribuire al decoro urbano per due settimane durante le vacanze. Nelle periferie non si sono interrotte le costruzioni di nuovi quartieri popolari. Nulla – in apparenza – lascia pensare a un Paese in stato d’allerta militare e tuttavia l’ordinaria normalità urbana è altrettanto angosciante, il che non si spiega se non con l’ordinaria, atavica consuetudine all’idea di guerra, che nella Russia di Putin è un pensiero come un altro. «Le sanzioni sono state un incredibile strumento di sviluppo, noi diamo il meglio quando siamo messi nell’angolo», ci diceva Ivan Kazankov,L’arma silenziosa «Dal 2019 i fatturati dei prodotti trasformati sono cresciuti di sessanta miliardi di dollari l’anno», diceva Kazankov. «L’obiettivo fissato da PutinSussidi dallo Stato per le esportazioni Viaggiando nelle fertili pianure del medio Volga era evidente come l’industria agroalimentare è diventata parte dell’economia di guerra, al pari di quella pesante – distese sterminate di girasoli, orzo, frumento, granoturco. Terra nera come la pece, pascoli di smeraldo, allevamenti di bovini degni del Nebraska. Le fattorie collettive abbandonate negli anni Novanta vengono acquisite dai grandi gruppi fedeli al regime. Dei 56 milioni di ettari rimasti incolti negli anni Novanta ne sono rimasti una trentina. Secondo la Fao la Russia da sola può sfamare due miliardi di persone. E il cambiamento climatico (per ora) gioca a favore di Putin, perché aumentano le terre coltivabili ovunque, non solo nelle pianure del Volga centrale, dove le stagioni di crescita sono più lunghe e i raccolti migliori – «una benedizione» diceva Kazankov – ma anche nella regione degli Urali e addirittura in Siberia. Pure sul riscaldamento globale la Russia sembra su un altro pianeta e in un’altra era geologica. Un mondo immobile che diventa opprimente quando si spalanca il grande spazio pieno di nulla, quando la pianura s’espande e dilaga in un monotono alternarsi di monotone foreste.Tra città e steppe © RIPRODUZIONE RISERVATA di Peppe Aquaro di Maria Elena Viggiano di Valeriano Musiu di Alessio Cozzolino di Peppe Aquaro

author: Pastor John Stone North Platte Berean Church
title: From the Pulpit: Devastating unforgiveness
text:
Harboring unforgiveness is spiritually devastating. Consider the sobering words of Jesus when his followers asked him to teach them how to pray: “Forgive us our trespasses as we forgive those who trespass against us.” In other words, we’re prayerfully asking God to forgive us in the same manner and degree that we’re forgiving others who have wronged us. Thus, if we’re holding onto unforgiveness, we’re actually inviting the Lord to hold on to unforgiveness toward us!
Perhaps even more pointedly, Jesus tells the story in Matthew 18 of a man who had been forgiven an incredible amount of debt owed to a king. He gratefully leaves the king a completely free man. Sadly, once forgiven, the forgiven man finds another man who owed him a comparatively paltry sum. When the second man is unable to repay him, in anger and unforgiveness, he chokes his debtor while demanding repayment. Word of his hypocrisy reaches the king who rescinds his offer of forgiveness and instead throws the first man in jail until his reinstated debt is paid off. Jesus ends with this sobering statement, “So also my heavenly Father will do to every one of you, if you do not forgive your brother from your heart.”
Clearly, we endanger ourselves spiritually when we refuse to forgive others as we’ve been forgiven by God. Before we talk about what forgiveness is, let’s first address three forgiveness misconceptions. First, we’ve probably heard “forgive and forget,” but these are not synonymous. Consider that God doesn’t “forget” our sin when he forgives. He doesn’t forget anything as he knows everything. He simply chooses not to treat us as our sins deserve (Psalm 103:10).
Forgiveness doesn’t mean that I bury the memories of being wronged or act like it didn’t happen. Second, forgiveness and reconciliation don’t always walk hand in hand. This is so hard as our sins can often have devastatingly far-reaching consequences that break relationships with others. One day, all relationships in Christ will be reconciled perfectly, but in this life, I may forgive someone and still fail to be reconciled to them relationally. May we be people who continually ask God for reconciliation with those whom we’ve wronged and by whom we’ve been wronged.
Finally, forgiveness doesn’t act like nothing happened or grant trust to someone who is not trustworthy. Forgiveness doesn’t require that we have the same relationship we had prior to the wrong that happened — that’s just naivete. We’re not condoning or tolerating the wrong when we forgive.
Instead, forgiveness begins with a recognition that a debt has been incurred against me by another person (e.g. they tarnished my reputation, betrayed my trust, stole my peace, etc.). That debt cannot simply be erased or ignored. It must be paid. Forgiveness is my decision to self-pay the debt that the other person has incurred against me. They did the wrong, but I’ll pay the cost of resolving the debt! Wait, that sounds so incredibly unfair! I’m the victim here, the one who has been wronged!
Indeed, nothing about forgiveness is “fair.” It’s incredibly gracious. And it’s exactly what has been done for believers in Jesus Christ through his perfect life, sacrificial death, powerful resurrection and glorious ascension. Just as God, our king, has paid for our innumerable sins, how can I not forgive and pay as generously as he has? And what does that look like? Next month, we’ll talk practically about how we practice this same forgiveness we’ve been shown in Christ.
